conclusion: The problem involves determining the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on a current-carrying wire folded into a right-angle shape in a uniform magnetic field.
The wire is folded into a right-angle shape with side lengths ac = L and cd = 2L, placed in a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the wire.
The total length of the wire is 3L, the magnetic induction intensity is B, and the current flowing through the wire is I.
The formula for the Ampere force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is F = I L × B, where L is the vector representing the length of the conductor and B is the magnetic field vector.
Since the wire is folded into a right-angle shape, we need to consider the effective length of the wire that is perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The wire can be divided into three segments: ac, cb, and bd. Only the segments perpendicular to the magnetic field will experience a force.

The segment ac is perpendicular to the magnetic field, and the segment bd is also perpendicular to the magnetic field. The segment cb is parallel to the magnetic field and will not experience a force.
The segment ac has a length of L, and the segment bd has a length of 2L.
The total effective length of the wire that is perpendicular to the magnetic field is L + 2L = 3L.
The magnitude of the Ampere force is given by F = I × L_perpendicular × B, where L_perpendicular = 3L.
Substituting the values, the magnitude of the Ampere force is F = I × 3L × B = 3ILB.
